stream_context.summary: Kaze spends a bonus day off adding content and fixing bugs in the desert-themed "cowboy town" level.  Major work includes upgrading trains, adding bandits, coins, and getting the Pokey enemy working after a deep technical dive, all while juggling severe N64 RAM limits that force the removal of the planned Yoshi Ranch area.

development_findings.summary: Trains now have VFX, SFX, camera shake and visible wheel rotation to make them feel dynamic
development_findings.quote: They now have VFX, they have SFX, they have the camera shake and they do that to you.

development_findings.summary: Bandit NPCs steal goods from the hat and tumbleweed stores; this narrative device eliminates the need to model shop interiors and saves RAM
development_findings.quote: This is a trick we do so we don't actually have to 3D model the stuff here because we are getting pretty close to running out of RAM.

development_findings.summary: Severe memory pressure (≈49 MB in-level) forced cutting the entire Yoshi Ranch area and reducing collision and geometry counts
development_findings.quote: We are out of memory… I’m fine with cutting out the Yoshi Ranch. I think that was unnecessary fluff anyway.

development_findings.summary: Pokey enemy was broken because Kaze’s engine skipped floor ray-casts when objects were stationary; vanilla Pokey expects 37 ray-casts per frame.  He re-enabled floor checks, fixed billboard scaling, and adjusted spawn/despawn ranges
development_findings.quote: Pokey needed the floor to be Raycasted every tick… now it works and I’m putting him everywhere.

development_findings.summary: Coins were placed along train tracks to encourage exploration, but coin count is kept low to avoid performance crashes
Added cowboy Yoshis, cowboy Toad sheriff, shy-guy commuter NPC, and planned ‘shifty guy’ Yoshi-coin gimmick to make the town feel alive
Design decisions constrained by N64 memory: data-per-area loading is hard in decomp; Kaze resorts to geo culling, IGNORE_RENDER tags, and trimming animations
Badub’s soundtrack re-uses about 70 % of the original SM64 sound-font but in ‘creative ways’ to sound fresh yet familiar
development_findings.quote: It sounds like a completely new soundtrack with a similar vibe to me. That’s what I want anyway.

development_findings.summary: Chain-chomp NPC follows a spline path and can reverse direction; showcases reusable path-following code

context_findings.summary: Kaze is on a week-long vacation from his day job at Gears for Breakfast and streams as a ‘bonus’ activity
context_findings.quote: I have a week off work and I decided to just do a bonus stream.

context_findings.summary: Frustrated that PayPal froze his old German account, breaking donation music requests during the stream
context_findings.quote: They asked me to verify my identity three months ago… now they just closed my account basically.

context_findings.summary: Admits physical fatigue from recent 315-lb bench-press PR; considers adding rest days
Expresses strong dislike for 2D platformers, boss fights, and verbose language—prefers concise, precise design
Cynical view of ROM-hack competitions: believes winners are audience-driven regardless of stated rules
context_findings.quote: I’ve always said, you don’t win comps by making good hacks. You win it by playing to the audience.

biobak.summary: Gives feedback on metallic look of Bandit’s teeth; dialog shows ongoing graphic polish loop

badub.summary: Soundtrack praised for creative use of default SM64 instruments; 70 % old sound-font, 30 % new feel

zeina.summary: Assigned to create tumbleweed store model/animations and Pokey animations
zeina.quote: I gotta ask Zeina to make a tumbleweed store here.

key_stories.title: Pokey Debug Saga
key_stories.summary: The Pokey enemy spawned invisible and floating.  Kaze discovered his engine optimization removed essential floor ray-casts, clashing with vanilla behavior.
key_stories.challenge: Pokey segments instantly despawned or hovered in mid-air.
key_stories.process: Instrumented code, compared to vanilla, traced to missing 37 per-frame ray-casts and billboard scaling issues; re-enabled floor checks and fixed scale.
key_stories.outcome: Pokeys render and behave correctly; spawn distance increased and scattered through the level.
key_stories.key_quote: Remember when I said that I wouldn’t be surprised? … They needed the floor to be Raycasted every tick.

key_stories.title: Running Out of RAM
key_stories.summary: The desert course exceeded memory limits, crashing the game.
key_stories.challenge: Level used ~40 k triangles plus placeholder songs, hitting 64 MB cap.
key_stories.process: Used memory overlay tool, removed Yoshi Ranch area, trimmed collision, deleted unused animations, added IGNORE_RENDER tags.
key_stories.outcome: Level now loads; Yoshi Ranch officially cut.
key_stories.key_quote: We are out of memory… I’m fine with cutting out the Yoshi Ranch.

key_stories.title: Donation Chaos
key_stories.summary: Viewers’ song requests didn’t play because Streamlabs sent money to Kaze’s closed German PayPal.
key_stories.challenge: Donations routed to wrong email; PayPal frozen for months.
key_stories.process: Checked Streamlabs settings, email accounts, PayPal notices live on-stream.
key_stories.key_quote: It just goes to the wrong email address. This makes no sense.

key_stories.title: Train Makeover
key_stories.summary: Trains were bland; Kaze enhanced them for immersion.
key_stories.process: Added particle VFX, sound effects, camera shake, wheel rotation, and NPC commentary about their speed.
key_stories.outcome: Trains feel lively and threaten player; shy-guy NPC hints they’re obstacles.
key_stories.key_quote: Look at the train wheels. Isn’t that cool?

key_stories.title: Bandits as Memory Hack
key_stories.summary: Needed lively storefronts without extra models.
key_stories.challenge: Modeling hat/tumbleweed inventory would exceed RAM.
key_stories.process: Introduced two bandits who ‘stole’ all goods; shopkeepers complain via dialogue.
key_stories.outcome: Narrative justification removes need for additional assets.
key_stories.key_quote: So we don’t actually have to 3D model the stuff here because we are getting pretty close to running out of RAM.
